awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cross-linguistic activation of referential bias in second-language learners of English
awd_abstract_narration:
Bilingualism is the norm in many parts of the world. Understanding how bilingual speakers derive meaning in context is thus not only an interesting research question about how the human mind accommodates the regular use of two or more languages in daily life, but one that has direct implications for applied language professionals, such as interpreters, teachers, and speech-language pathologists working with bilinguals. Previous research has shown that bilinguals' knowledge of one language can affect how they say and interpret words and sentences in the other. This is called cross-linguistic activation. The goal of this dissertation research is to contribute to our understanding of how cross-linguistic activation affects how bilinguals make sense of language in context, that is, beyond understanding individual words and sentences.  

The proposed research will provide insight into the effect of cross-linguistic activation at a word level on bilinguals' discourse level processing by investigating how the strength of referential biases associated with Korean predicates affects Korean-English bilinguals' referential processing in English. Verb-based implicit causality (IC) creates biases for who will be mentioned next; e.g., 'John threatened Bill' implies the subject ('John') was the cause of the 'threaten' event, making it the most likely next referent in the discourse. Korean, in addition to IC verbs, has a class of (subject-biased) syntactic causative (SC) constructions, best translated as 'causing X to be Y'. A preliminary study has shown that Korean speakers have stronger referential biases with SC constructions than with regular IC predicates in Korean. This project investigates the extent to which differences in bias strength associated with SC and IC predicates in Korean influence Korean-English bilinguals' offline and online reference processing in English. The project will collect data from Korean-speaking learners of English and native English speakers, using both written sentence completion (Experiment 1) and visual-world eye-tracking (Experiment 2) paradigms. In both experiments, potentially modulating effects of English language proficiency and learning experience on cross-linguistic activation in referential processing will be assessed.

por.por_cntn:
Bi- and multilingualism is the norm in many parts of the world, and use of English as a non-native language is paramount in many domains of life worldwide. This project contributes to our understanding of how bilingual speakers derive meaning in context, and in particular of the role of the native language in this process. The overall goal of this project is to see how Korean-speaking learners of English are affected by their knowledge of Korean when they produce and comprehend English sentences.

 

More specifically, we conducted a series of experiments that compared native and non-native English speakers in their understanding of a cause-and-effect relationship between sentences when the verb in a preceding sentence creates a bias toward a certain character as a cause of an event. A verb’s meaning may highlight different characters as an underlying cause in a sentence, such as Justin and Steve in the sentence “Justin frightened Steve”. There are certain verbs whose meaning places the focus either on the first or second character. For example, the verb frighten in a sentence like Justin frightened Steve draws attention to the first character Justin as the main cause of the event, whereas the verb fear in a sentence like Harry feared Fred highlights the second character Fred as the main cause of the event. Such biases to mentioning one of the characters dependent on a verb are called remention biases.

Importantly, the Korean translation equivalents of some of these verbs (e.g., frighten) are hypothesized to give rise to a stronger remention bias toward the first character due to explicit causative marking in the verb. The goal of this study is to see how Korean speakers differ from English speakers in their interpretation of the causal relationship that contains these verbs in their native language, and whether Korean-speaking learners of English carry over sentence interpretation patterns from their native language when they comprehend English sentences.

 

In our Korean and English sentence-completion tasks, Korean speakers rementioned the first character more following verbs with explicit causality marking, whereas English speakers showed no difference in remention bias for the English translation correspondents of these verbs, which did not contain explicit causality marking. Crucially, Korean-speaking learners of English showed the same stronger bias towards the first character when presented with these sentences in English. However, this pattern was found only in the untimed sentence-completion task, but not during real-time comprehension in the eye-tracking task. While both Korean-speaking learners and native English speakers showed proactive effects of remention bias in the real-time comprehension task, effects of crosslinguistic influence from Korean were detected only in the offline sentence-completion task. Learners’ overall English proficiency did not affect their performance in either of these tasks.    

 

From these findings, we have learned that bilinguals speaking both Korean and English have shared information regarding the interpretation of remention bias verbs, and importantly, they actively access the information from both languages when they comprehend sentences in their non-native language. The project contributes simultaneously to the psycholinguistic literature on remention bias, which has been dominated by studies with monolingual native speakers, and to our understanding of sentence comprehension in bilinguals.
